item.title: Calculus - Series
item.description:
WHY

A tool for solving some problems in Physics(TAYLOR POLYNOMIALS, etc.) and some situation.

Making Linear to Discrete.

WHAT

Sequences: A list of number written in a definite order

Series

Convergence of a Series

WHAT: What is convergence

$$ \forall \epsilon, \exist N, \forall n > N, |a_n - l| < \epsilon \rArr a_n \ convergent \ to \ l $$

E.g. $\frac{1}{x}$

$$ for \ all \ \epsilon, exist \ N = \frac{1}{\epsilon}, for \ all \ n > N, |a_n - 0| < \epsilon \rArr a_n \ convergent \ to \ 0 $$

Convergent = Bounded in both sides + Monotonically increasing or decreasing

  • Bounded in both sides

    • $\forall n, a_n \leq M$ and $\forall n, a_n \geq N$

  • Monotonically increasing or decreasing

    • $\forall n, a_n < a_{n+1}$ or $\forall n, a_n > a_{n+1}$

    Note. Identifying between decreasing and non-increasing

HOW: Continuity and convergence theorem

$$ if \ \lim_{n \rarr \infty}a_n = L, \lim_{n \rarr \infty}f(a_n) = f(L) (f \ is \ continuous \ at \ x = L) $$

$$ (1) \lim_{n \rarr \infty}a_n = L \rArr a_n \ converge \ to \ L $$ $$ (2) f(x): a_n = f(n), if \lim_{x \rarr \infty} = L, a_n \ converge \ to \ L $$ $$ (-1)^n: divergent $$ $$ when \ a_n, b_n \ convergent \rArr \lim{a + / \cdot b} = \lim{a} + \cdot \lim{b}; \lim{a \cdot ^\ c} = \lim{a} \cdot ^\ c $$ $$ a_n \leq b_n \leq c_n \rArr \lim{b_n} = L $$
